Award.AwardTitle: TC: Medium: Privacy and Declassification Policy Enforcement Framework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Information systems that handle personal information must adhere to
legal regulations, corporate privacy policies, and contractual
agreements designed to protect personal privacy. Relying exclusively
on application designers and developers for such assurances is
unrealistic. There is a need for methods and tools that can identify
errors in the handing of personal data and provide formal assurances
that personal information is handled appropriately.

This project is developing a software development framework that uses
novel language-based techniques to ensure that software enforces
privacy policies. Privacy policies (based on legal and regulatory
requirements) are formally specified in temporal logic, and identify
circumstances under which information can be shared (based on criteria
such as the roles of individuals involved, prior events, and whether
the data has been aggregated) and future obligations that are incurred
as a result of the information sharing. The framework consists of
policy analysis tools, a programming language, program analysis tools
that verify both privacy and declassification policies are enforced,
and a runtime environment. Used in concert, these components produce
distributed information systems that verifiably handle personal
information appropriately.

The framework being developed by this project will address problems
faced by many information systems. However, the project will focus
especially on the needs of the medical industry, both with respect to
patient records and clinical trials. As medical practice transitions
to electronic medical records, the need for high-assurance systems
becomes increasingly acute. This project will develop the
capabilities needed to verify that electronic medical records
systems comply with applicable privacy policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our society is becoming increasingly dependent on information systems for processing personal information about individuals, including their medical records and financial data. Improper disclosure of this information can be harmful to those individuals and bring down heavy financial penalties on the organizations. Electronic management of personal information must be held in strict compliance with the law, thus information systems designed for such purposes must have some guarantee of compliance. To aid in this endeavor, the research developed a general methodology for designing and implementing information systems to provide assurance that the process of personal information conforms to specific regulations. 

We first developed a policy specification language which can capture the privacy requirements of regulations, such as Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). We then created policy analysis techniques and associate tools to check whether an action is compliant with a regulation. Further, we designed an actor-based domain-specific language framework, called History-Aware Programming Language (HAPL), for creating systems that can be mechanically checked against privacy specifications. Finally, we applied this framework to implement a prototype Electronic Medical Record System (EMRS) that provably enforced the HIPAA policy rules using the approach we developed. These research contributions demonstrate that the direction of building information systems with verifiable privacy policy compliance is promising.

This research project has produced 25 high quality journal and conference publications. A tool was generated from the research results and has been made publicly available. This grant has provided training to a total of 12 students at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA), including three female students, three Hispanic/Latino students, and one undergraduate student. Being supported by this grant, four students obtained their doctoral degrees, and four students defended their M.S. theses successfully. Additionally, the research results have been integrated into two existing courses at UTSA.
